Photo by Brent Lewin/Bloomberg files Article Sidebar Share Share this Story: The Great Rethink: Cash is no longer king and the transition is going to be a high-stakes affair Copy Link Email Facebook Twitter Reddit Pinterest LinkedIn Tumblr Trending Article content The policy consensus that has guided economic decision-making for decades is being challenged like never before. In this series, the Financial Post explores the opportunities and unknown costs of the Great Rethink. Canadians have been tossing cash into Salvation Army kettles at Christmastime since 1903, long enough to become part of the holiday tradition. We apologize, but this video has failed to load. Try refreshing your browser, or tap here to see other videos from our team. The Great Rethink: Cash is no longer king and the transition is going to be a high-stakes affair Back to video “People are familiar with the idea of giving your child a loonie or a toonie or a dollar bill, depending on how old you are, and having them drop it in the bubble,” spokesperson Rob Kerr said. The experience will feel less familiar in 2020. The Salvation Army in November announced that its annual kettle fundraising campaign in Ontario would be “proactively taking a digital turn” by switching to a mostly online fundraising effort, via FilltheKettle.com, in COVID-19 hot spots. On Dec. 14, the Sally Ann said Christmas kettles would also be absent from Manitoba’s street corners and shopping malls due to the pandemic and the provincial government’s related restrictions. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued In another sign of the times, the charity on Dec. 1 said that hundreds of kettles were being equipped with “touchless giving technology,” provided by Canadian startup TipTapPay Micropayments Ltd. and powered by Rogers Communications Inc.’s wireless network, to allow donations via a credit card or smartphone. “This is the year when a lot of our traditions are shifting,” Kerr said in an interview on Nov. 24. The adjustments were necessary to protect volunteers from a highly contagious and deadly disease. But the Salvation Army, one of the country’s oldest charities, is now also one of a growing number of entities coming to grips with a simple fact: people are using cash much less often to pay for things, and that trend has all sorts of ramifications for central banks and society at large. Santa Claus collects donations for The Salvation Army at the Stony Plain Walmart in Edmonton, on Dec. 16, 2020. Photo by Ian Kucerak/Postmedia News The move to a cash-lite society has been happening for a while. Payments Canada, the non-profit that owns and operates this country’s payment clearing and settlement systems, found that the number of overall payment transactions by cash declined to 18.4 per cent in 2019 from 32.8 per cent in 2014. COVID-19 appears to have accelerated the trend. Some grew fearful of handling cash amid reports that it could be a conduit for the virus, but there has also been a shift to e-commerce fuelled by the forced closure of brick-and-mortar stores. Online sales by traditional retailers increased more than 74 per cent from a year earlier in September, according to Statistics Canada. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued It has all prompted some existential thinking about the future of money. Metal circles and paper bills with animals and monarchs stamped all over them are being hoarded, not spent, according to Bank of Canada data. In addition to cash and cards, consumers can now make payments using a variety of apps or “wearables,” such as smart watches. In some cases they are even experimenting with digital currencies. This trend may be creating a lot of convenience for consumers, but policy-makers see cash as a public good and, therefore, feel duty bound to ensure it (or, perhaps, something like it) is there for people to use. More On This Topic Digital cash may seem inevitable, but the Bank of Canada isn’t quite ready to concede Christine Lagarde says her ‘hunch’ is that ECB will adopt digital currency Bank of Canada says digital currencies need globally coordinated approach Pandemic accelerates need to consider digital currency: Bank of Canada Adding to that concern are the digital currencies being developed by both the private and public sectors, as widespread support by citizens for something other than the national currency could challenge a country’s control over its monetary affairs. Any of these factors would have been enough to get the attention of authorities. With all of them converging at once, Canadian central bankers and their allies abroad have been forced to speed up plans for digital currencies of their own, if only to ensure the groundwork is in place should the need to issue such a currency arise. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued If cash is no longer king, policymakers are at least thinking about the line of succession. “This is all looking a lot more urgent because of the speed with which technology is evolving,” Bank of Canada deputy governor Tim Lane said during a virtual panel discussion in October. “And, particularly, I think with COVID we’ve seen an acceleration of the shift of activities online, and that suggests that if we want to be ready to develop any kind of digital central bank product, we need to move faster than we thought was going to be necessary.” This is all looking a lot more urgent because of the speed with which technology is evolving Bank of Canada deputy governor Tim Lane Yet any tweak to money as we know it is bound to be a high-stakes proposition. Cash is hanging on for a reason: anyone can use it. You don’t need a smartphone to hand someone a cash payment. Physical currency also offers privacy, something authorities in democratic countries say they want to protect, even if it keeps some of them up at night over concerns such as money laundering. Still, cash was in decline even before the pandemic. As electronic and contactless payments have surged, the combined monetary value of cash transactions shrank to 0.9 per cent of total transactions in 2019, from 1.4 per cent in 2014, Payments Canada noted in its annual trends report. Cash is hanging on for a reason: anyone can use it. Photo by Francis Racine/Cornwall Standard-Freeholder/Postmedia Network files “What we are starting to see is extensions of trends that have already occurred,” Tracey Black, chief executive of Payments Canada, said. The trend away from cash has likely gained further momentum during the pandemic, partly because a number of people have likely come to see bills and coins as virus carriers. Payments Canada in a recent survey found that 42 per cent of Canadians polled were uncomfortable handling cash in general. Even post-pandemic, approximately 34 per cent of those surveyed did not expect to return to using cash as much as they did pre-COVID-19. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued The Bank of Canada urged retailers in the earlier days of the pandemic to keep accepting cash to ensure everyone could buy what they need. More recently, Bank of England research found that the risk of transmitting COVID-19 via banknotes is low. However, Payments Canada noted in its annual trends report that fewer than five per cent of Canadians have used a virtual currency, such as Bitcoin, to make a recent purchase. This is partly why the Bank of Canada in February said it saw no reason yet to create digital cash, although it also said it still had to be ready to do so just in case. Those statements came after Facebook Inc. created a stir last year by announcing plans to back a digital currency, Libra, which was recently rebranded as Diem. Members of the Diem Association — which still aims to launch a payment system with “Diem Coins” backed by cash and short-term government debt — include Ottawa-based Shopify Inc. and Spotify Technology SA. Facebook created a stir last year by announcing plans to back a digital currency, Libra. Photo by Dado Ruvic/Reuters Illustration files The Libra announcement caught the attention of policy-makers, who pushed back against the original vision, hence the recent rebrand and tweaks to the overall vision. Still, one of the concerns was that if enough people used something like a Libra/Diem “stablecoin,” it could sideline monetary gatekeepers such as the Bank of Canada. If too many Canadians conduct their financial affairs in a currency other than the dollar, they won’t much care about the setting of interest rates, making it harder for the central bank to manage inflation. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued This sort of concern, as well as innovation and the proliferation of digital payment options, has central banks thinking about their own central bank digital currency (CBDC). A survey of 66 central banks published earlier this year found approximately 80 per cent of them were doing some kind of CBDC-related work as of 2019, up from around 70 per cent a year earlier. The digital cash these banks could ultimately issue would not replace physical cash entirely, but might instead be accepted alongside it, as another form of payment backed by the government. CBDC, Payments Canada explained in another recent report, “is a digital liability of the central bank” that can be used to pay for things. In other words, similar to cash. The Bank of Canada would be on the hook for its digital currency, which citizens could use to spend on things the same way they would with bank notes. Issuing a CBDC could also “potentially counter” a threat such as Libra, Bank of Canada staffers said back in February. Some countries have already taken the CBDC concept for a test drive. Sweden’s central bank has piloted an “e-krona,” the Bahamas has launched a digital “Sand Dollar” and China is readying a central-bank-backed virtual currency of its own. In February, the Bank of Canada signalled it was working on a contingency plan for the day it might need a digital currency in the event that cash stopped being widely accepted or private digital currencies became all the rage. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued COVID-19 has hastened that planning. In November, now-former Bank of Canada senior deputy governor Carolyn Wilkins said the central bank had “stepped up our work on central bank digital currency, given that COVID-19 has accelerated the move to digital payments.” The Bank of Canada also joined with the European, Japanese, Swedish, Swiss, English and U.S. central banks in October in publishing “common foundational principles and core features” of CBDCs. According to those guidelines, issuing a digital currency shouldn’t upend the financial system, such as by causing a bank run if people pull their money from commercial lenders and put it into virtual cash. The central banks also said a digital currency should “coexist with and complement existing forms of money,” and spark innovation and efficiency. A conveyer belt with objects is used to demonstrate blockchain technology. Photo by David Becker/Getty Images files Central bankers identified 14 core features of any CBDC, including that it should be as easy to use as cash. There would also need to be a ledger to keep track of things, which could look similar to the blockchain technology that underpins Bitcoin. The central banks also see potential for digital currencies to be used in ways beyond everyday payments, such as when governments need to speedily send funds to citizens in need, as they have during the pandemic. The Bank of Canada back in February touched on a few other reasons as to why a digital currency would be helpful. For one, if everyone started using a digital currency created by a private company, a lender of last resort such as the Bank of Canada can’t start cranking out that currency to bail out commercial financial institutions in a crisis. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued Moreover, having a private company in charge of a widely used currency could go against the public’s interest, since that company would naturally be guided by a profit motive, not necessarily what’s best for society at large. The Bank of Canada maintains that it has an obligation to ensure that every Canadian has access to a unit of exchange they can use for free. That’s one of the reasons policy-makers are so protective of cash. But the main reason a central bank would issue a digital currency is probably control, specifically, the fear of losing control of monetary matters to a company or another country. The Bank of Canada designs and distributes bank notes, but also takes steps to help ensure money keeps its value by setting interest rates in a way that keeps prices stable. The monetary sovereignty of a country could be jeopardized if a company or another country’s digital currency gained enough traction. The Bank of Canada designs and distributes bank notes, but also takes steps to help ensure money keeps its value. Photo by Brent Lewin/Bloomberg files “A risk of stablecoins, so-called ‘cryptocurrencies’ and foreign CBDCs is that domestic users adopt them in significant numbers and use of the domestic sovereign currency dwindles,” the October report from the Bank of Canada and other central banks said. “In extremis, such a ‘digital dollarisation’ could see a national currency substituted by another with the domestic central bank gradually losing control over monetary matters.” That risk could be compounded depending on who is providing the hot new currency. China, noted Barry Campbell, a former parliamentary secretary to the minister of finance, has aimed to increase the global importance of its currency. Being a digital currency trailblazer could help those efforts. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued “It’s actually a geopolitical issue, it’s not just an issue over dollars and cents,” said Campbell, now president of Toronto-based lobbying firm Campbell Strategies Inc., of CBDCs. “This working group of the central banks … is an indication of just how seriously central banks are starting to look at this and, if you will, protect their turf.” Perhaps with this in mind, Bank of Canada staffers said in a June report that the central bank was looking at “multiple formats” for a digital currency, including the use of a “custom device that is engineered for universal access while securely storing and transferring a CBDC.” These universal access devices (UAD) “could incorporate attributes of cash and take advantage of specialized technologies,” the report said. Those cash-like features could include making it wallet-sized and allowing for small transactions. This working group … is an indication of just how seriously central banks are starting to look at this and, if you will, protect their turf Barry Campbell, former parliamentary secretary to the minister of finance “They have to be ready in case the necessity arises that they have to provide a digital alternative to cash,” said Thorsten Koeppl, an economics professor at Queen’s University in Kingston, Ont. Yet the death of cash is likely years away, if it ever actually happens. In April, for instance, Bank of Canada staffers, working with Ipsos and Statistics Canada, found that 74 per cent of the people they surveyed had no plans to go cashless. “I think inclusion is something that we really have to continue to monitor, and to make sure that there’s always an opportunity for people who prefer to use cash as tender to be able to purchase the things that they need,” Black, at Payments Canada, said. “I think cash is going to be around for quite some time.” Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued A digital Canadian currency is likely some ways off as well, even as Payments Canada modernizes its systems and the federal government examines the concept of open banking, which could allow consumers to securely share transaction data with third-party financial service providers. The Bank of Canada in February noted that it will take “several years” to build the capacity to issue a cash-like CBDC, in addition to support from the federal government. The bank also noted that there are other ways to respond to a cashless economy or a boom in private digital currencies, including targeted regulation and improved payment systems, both of which are in the works. The Bank of Canada building in Ottawa. Photo by Geoff Robins/AFP via Getty Images files A Canadian CBDC is not a sure thing and policy-makers at this point are really just getting cash’s affairs in order. In the meantime, there are still plenty of people relying on it. Kerr at the Salvation Army said the majority of donations had been coming in the form of cash tossed into the bubbles placed in and around places where people shop. Those bills and coins help fund the food banks, shelters and substance-use recovery programs the charity operates. This year’s Christmas kettle campaign was targeting $23 million in donations. Hitting that amount in a normal year would have taken plenty of work and generosity, even before factoring in declining cash use and the coronavirus pandemic. But the “touchless giving units” are expected to help. According to Tiptap, a pilot of the devices on Salvation Army kettles last year in Toronto led to three times the donation amounts at those bubbles compared to cash-only ones. “It is,” Kerr said, “a new day.” Financial Post • Email: gzochodne@nationalpost.com | Twitter: GeoffZochodne Share this article in your social network Share this Story: The Great Rethink: Cash is no longer king and the transition is going to be a high-stakes affair Copy Link Email Facebook Twitter Reddit Pinterest LinkedIn Tumblr In-depth reporting on the innovation economy from The Logic, brought to you in partnership with the Financial Post. Fear of coronavirus-tainted money grows in U.S., opening new front in the war on cash | Financial Post Skip to Content POSTHASTE Sharpen your focus before your workday Sharpen your focus before your workday Sign up now> Sections Search Search financialpost.com Perform search Financial Post Share Share this Story: Fear of coronavirus-tainted money grows in U.S., opening new front in the war on cash Copy Link Email Facebook Twitter Reddit Pinterest LinkedIn TumblrSubscribe Main Menu Search financialpost.com Perform search News Archives Personal Finance MoneyWise Business Essentials Debt Family Finance Taxes Retirement Young Money High Net Worth FP Comment FP Picks Investing Investing Pro Markets Economy Executive Women Entrepreneur Small Business Real Estate Commercial Real Estate Mortgages Commodities Agriculture Energy Mining Innovation Post Arcade Information Technology FP Magazine CEO of the Year FP500 National Post Videos More Holiday Guide Shopping Essentials Cannabis Executive Legal Post Podcasts Posthaste Retail Transportation Classifieds Place a Classifieds ad Obituaries Place a Notice Jobs News Personal Finance FP Comment FP Picks Investing Markets Economy Executive Women Entrepreneur Real Estate Commodities Innovation National Post Videos Breadcrumb Trail Links News FP Street Fear of coronavirus-tainted money grows in U.S., opening new front in the war on cash Some industry groups and banks have been urging the Federal Reserve to assure Americans there's minimal risk for using cash Author of the article: Bloomberg News Jenny Surane, Olivia Rockeman and Robert Schmidt Publishing date:Mar 11, 2020 • • 5 minute read The Fed has been putting notes repatriated from Asia in quarantine for up to 10 days to ensure it's safe. Photo by Getty Images/iStockphoto Article Sidebar Share Share this Story: Fear of coronavirus-tainted money grows in U.S., opening new front in the war on cash Copy Link Email Facebook Twitter Reddit Pinterest LinkedIn Tumblr Trending Article content The signs began appearing around Seattle in the windows of Dick’s Drive-In, the city’s iconic burger chain: “In an abundance of caution, we ask you to please pay with credit or debit card if possible rather than cash.” Fear of dollars is now palpable in the U.S. epicentre of the coronavirus. We apologize, but this video has failed to load. Try refreshing your browser, or tap here to see other videos from our team. Fear of coronavirus-tainted money grows in U.S., opening new front in the war on cash Back to video And across the financial industry, a rigorous debate is brewing over how to address the public’s mounting concern that greenbacks might transmit COVID-19. Studies show it’s at least theoretically possible for other coronaviruses to survive on the dollar’s cotton-and-linen weave, though there’s little agreement on the actual risk of contagion. More On This Topic McDonald’s ordering kiosks have a major flaw, making them unusable for large number of customers Google Pay to offer personal chequing accounts in partnership with American bank, credit union In Sweden, cash is almost extinct and people implant microchips in their hands to pay for things Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued Behind the scenes, some industry groups and banks have been urging the Federal Reserve and Treasury Department to issue a statement assuring Americans that there’s minimal risk for using cash, according to people with knowledge of the discussions. The Fed, in turn, says it’s waiting for advice from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which so far has said the virus spreads primarily through person-to-person contact. In the meantime, the Fed has been putting notes repatriated from Asia in quarantine for up to 10 days to ensure it’s safe. The stakes are high for banks and companies handling electronic payments: Billions of dollars in profits hinge on whatever statement or policy authorities ultimately issue. On one side, small and mid-size banks are working to keep branches open so they can keep serving legions of business customers that refill their cash registers daily. Representatives from some lenders think it’s important for regulators to offer guidance on handling money, noting the risk of using currency is low — comparing it, say, to pushing an elevator button or grasping a handrail. ‘Hygienic’ Payments If, on the other hand, authorities take steps that discourage the use of dollar bills, it will buttress the credit card industry’s long-running “war on cash,” sending more transactions through their networks and to payment apps that collect fees. That could even boost interest-bearing credit card balances. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued Firms such as Visa Inc., Mastercard Inc., American Express Co., PayPal Holdings Inc. and a slew of large card-issuing banks would be among the top beneficiaries. Visa and Mastercard credit cards. Photo by Daniel Acker/Bloomberg files The virus may end up serving as a “trigger event” for wider acceptance of cards long term, either persuading retailers to start taking them or prompting the government to force them, said Lisa Ellis, an analyst independent research boutique MoffettNathanson. The shift would be especially dramatic in regions of the world where card use is still relatively uncommon, she said. “Digital payments are already viewed as good for society by governments because they help with financial inclusion, they drive tax revenue and eliminate corruption,” she said. “This is another reason: ‘Oh, and it’s hygienic too.'” Fighting for Poor And on another side are millions of Americans who lack access to bank accounts, as well as poor and rural communities with few if any branches serving residents and local businesses. Many of them rely on cash for commerce. Repeatedly in recent years, consumer advocates have fought stores and restaurants that try to simplify checkout by going “cashless.” Cities such as New York, Philadelphia and San Francisco passed laws requiring dollars be accepted. Some of those groups worry they’re about to face a national battle to allow cashless commerce in response to the coronavirus. “Going cashless is definitely not something that we particularly support,” said Eric Espinoza, an associate director at Neighborhood Trust Financial Partners, which helps provide financial services to low-income communities. “We certainly wouldn’t support it under a hasty decision-making environment in which you’re extremely reactive and potentially not as thoughtful about the repercussions.” Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued Despite the increased popularity of credit and debit cards in recent years, cash still remains one of the most popular ways to pay for things in the U.S., accounting for 26 per cent of all payments by consumers last year, according to data compiled by the Fed. Spare change and dollar bills are still overwhelmingly favoured for small purchases, accounting for about 50 per cent of payments under $10. Cash still remains one of the most popular ways to pay for things in the U.S. Photo by Daniel Acker/Bloomberg Roughly 25 per cent of Americans are either unbanked or underbanked — with black and Hispanic households making up the largest percentage of those lacking accounts, according to a study by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. More than half of unbanked households in the U.S. say they lack the funds to keep an account open. “If you want to go that direction, it’s going to take really thoughtful planning in order to deal with the questions of inclusivity,” John Thompson, chief program officer for the Financial Health Network. “There’s still really important, substantively sized sectors of the country that are operating outside of the mainstream financial system.” Paper currency in the U.S. is made from 75 per cent cotton and 25 per cent linen, according to the Treasury. That makes the surface of bills coarse and fibrous, allowing germs to adhere more easily and survive longer than they can on smooth objects. One study in 2013 showed the dollar has the ability to show “significant and prolonged carriage” of the dreaded Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus bacteria known as MSRA. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued A 2020 study of coronaviruses, which included SARS and MERS, showed the microbes can persist on surfaces for as long as nine days. That can be reduced significantly using ethanol-based disinfectant, according to the study, but cleaning a paper bill proves more difficult than a plastic surface like a desk. Confronted with COVID-19, the People’s Bank of China began using ultraviolet light and high-temperature ovens to disinfect cash coming in. It has also replaced old notes with newly minted bills. The People’s Bank of China began using ultraviolet light and high-temperature ovens to disinfect cash coming in. Photo by Fred Dugour/AFP/Getty Images files The Fed is staying in contact with the CDC to make sure it’s aware of the agency’s latest thinking on how the virus spreads, a spokeswoman for the central bank said. So far during the current outbreak, the Fed hasn’t widely enacted its longstanding protocol for banks handling bills suspected of being dangerous: First stacking them in “straps” of 100, then bundling those into larger bricks and packaging them in plastic bags with the word “CONTAMINATED” scribbled in permanent ink. Even if the virus compels more people to use cards, the world’s largest payments network will still be battling the broader slowdown in spending, especially in the travel sector. “In the near term, at this point, coronavirus is a clear negative because of disproportionate impact on international travel and consumer discretionary spend,” Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. analyst Harshita Rawat said in an interview. “People are just not traveling internationally and this is one of the most profitable businesses that these companies have.” Bloomberg.com Share this article in your social network Share this Story: Fear of coronavirus-tainted money grows in U.S., opening new front in the war on cash Copy Link Email Facebook Twitter Reddit Pinterest LinkedIn Tumblr In-depth reporting on the innovation economy from The Logic, brought to you in partnership with the Financial Post. Canada to boost screening of UK travelers, sees no sign of mutated COVID-19 | Financial Post Skip to Content POSTHASTE Sharpen your focus before your workday Sharpen your focus before your workday Sign up now> Sections Search Search financialpost.com Perform search Financial Post Share Share this Story: Canada to boost screening of UK travelers, sees no sign of mutated COVID-19 Copy Link Email Facebook Twitter Reddit LinkedIn TumblrSubscribe Main Menu Search financialpost.com Perform search News Archives Personal Finance MoneyWise Business Essentials Debt Family Finance Taxes Retirement Young Money High Net Worth FP Comment FP Picks Investing Investing Pro Markets Economy Executive Women Entrepreneur Small Business Real Estate Commercial Real Estate Mortgages Commodities Agriculture Energy Mining Innovation Post Arcade Information Technology FP Magazine CEO of the Year FP500 National Post Videos More Holiday Guide Shopping Essentials Cannabis Executive Legal Post Podcasts Posthaste Retail Transportation Classifieds Place a Classifieds ad Obituaries Place a Notice Jobs News Personal Finance FP Comment FP Picks Investing Markets Economy Executive Women Entrepreneur Real Estate Commodities Innovation National Post Videos Breadcrumb Trail Links PMN Business Canada to boost screening of UK travelers, sees no sign of mutated COVID-19 Author of the article: Reuters David Ljunggren and Julie Gordon Publishing date:Dec 22, 2020 • • 1 minute read Article content OTTAWA — Canada is introducing extra measures to screen people who have spent time in Britain to check for a fast-spreading mutated COVID-19 variant, Public Safety Minister Bill Blair told a briefing on Tuesday. Separately, health officials said they had seen no sign yet of the variant, which emerged first in Britain and prompted many countries to introduce travel bans. We apologize, but this video has failed to load. Try refreshing your browser, or tap here to see other videos from our team. Canada to boost screening of UK travelers, sees no sign of mutated COVID-19 Back to video Although Ottawa imposed a 72-hour block on flights from Britain on Sunday, Blair said more steps were needed to handle people who had been in the country and then flown to Canada via Europe or the United States. Visitors to Britain during the previous two weeks prior to arrival in Canada will be referred to health officials for additional assessments, screening and questions. They will also have to go into quarantine for 14 days. “We believe (these measures) are among the strongest in the world,” Blair said, adding that those who lied about having not been in Britain could face imprisonment and big fines. Fewer than 2% of coronavirus cases in Canada have been linked to international travel, Blair said. A second wave of coronavirus is sweeping across Canada and authorities have only just begun to inoculate the population using Pfizer’s vaccine. Health Minister Patty Hajdu said a decision on whether to approve Moderna Inc’s vaccine should come very soon but gave no details. Ontario, Canada’s most populous province, on Monday announced a partial shutdown of some businesses starting Dec. 26 and banned most indoor gatherings. Cases continue to rise steadily and chief public health officer Theresa Tam said she was particularly worried about the increasing number of people being hospitalized at a time when health care workers are exhausted. “It’s going to be much more difficult for us to manage in the next few months,” she said. Photo by Brent Lewin/Bloomberg files Article Sidebar Share Share this Story: The Great Rethink: Cash is no longer king and the transition is going to be a high-stakes affair Copy Link Email Facebook Twitter Reddit Pinterest LinkedIn Tumblr Trending Article content The policy consensus that has guided economic decision-making for decades is being challenged like never before. In this series, the Financial Post explores the opportunities and unknown costs of the Great Rethink. Canadians have been tossing cash into Salvation Army kettles at Christmastime since 1903, long enough to become part of the holiday tradition. We apologize, but this video has failed to load. Try refreshing your browser, or tap here to see other videos from our team. The Great Rethink: Cash is no longer king and the transition is going to be a high-stakes affair Back to video “People are familiar with the idea of giving your child a loonie or a toonie or a dollar bill, depending on how old you are, and having them drop it in the bubble,” spokesperson Rob Kerr said. The experience will feel less familiar in 2020. The Salvation Army in November announced that its annual kettle fundraising campaign in Ontario would be “proactively taking a digital turn” by switching to a mostly online fundraising effort, via FilltheKettle.com, in COVID-19 hot spots. On Dec. 14, the Sally Ann said Christmas kettles would also be absent from Manitoba’s street corners and shopping malls due to the pandemic and the provincial government’s related restrictions. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued In another sign of the times, the charity on Dec. 1 said that hundreds of kettles were being equipped with “touchless giving technology,” provided by Canadian startup TipTapPay Micropayments Ltd. and powered by Rogers Communications Inc.’s wireless network, to allow donations via a credit card or smartphone. “This is the year when a lot of our traditions are shifting,” Kerr said in an interview on Nov. 24. The adjustments were necessary to protect volunteers from a highly contagious and deadly disease. But the Salvation Army, one of the country’s oldest charities, is now also one of a growing number of entities coming to grips with a simple fact: people are using cash much less often to pay for things, and that trend has all sorts of ramifications for central banks and society at large. Santa Claus collects donations for The Salvation Army at the Stony Plain Walmart in Edmonton, on Dec. 16, 2020. Photo by Ian Kucerak/Postmedia News The move to a cash-lite society has been happening for a while. Payments Canada, the non-profit that owns and operates this country’s payment clearing and settlement systems, found that the number of overall payment transactions by cash declined to 18.4 per cent in 2019 from 32.8 per cent in 2014. COVID-19 appears to have accelerated the trend. Some grew fearful of handling cash amid reports that it could be a conduit for the virus, but there has also been a shift to e-commerce fuelled by the forced closure of brick-and-mortar stores. Online sales by traditional retailers increased more than 74 per cent from a year earlier in September, according to Statistics Canada. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued It has all prompted some existential thinking about the future of money. Metal circles and paper bills with animals and monarchs stamped all over them are being hoarded, not spent, according to Bank of Canada data. In addition to cash and cards, consumers can now make payments using a variety of apps or “wearables,” such as smart watches. In some cases they are even experimenting with digital currencies. This trend may be creating a lot of convenience for consumers, but policy-makers see cash as a public good and, therefore, feel duty bound to ensure it (or, perhaps, something like it) is there for people to use. More On This Topic Digital cash may seem inevitable, but the Bank of Canada isn’t quite ready to concede Christine Lagarde says her ‘hunch’ is that ECB will adopt digital currency Bank of Canada says digital currencies need globally coordinated approach Pandemic accelerates need to consider digital currency: Bank of Canada Adding to that concern are the digital currencies being developed by both the private and public sectors, as widespread support by citizens for something other than the national currency could challenge a country’s control over its monetary affairs. Any of these factors would have been enough to get the attention of authorities. With all of them converging at once, Canadian central bankers and their allies abroad have been forced to speed up plans for digital currencies of their own, if only to ensure the groundwork is in place should the need to issue such a currency arise. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued If cash is no longer king, policymakers are at least thinking about the line of succession. “This is all looking a lot more urgent because of the speed with which technology is evolving,” Bank of Canada deputy governor Tim Lane said during a virtual panel discussion in October. “And, particularly, I think with COVID we’ve seen an acceleration of the shift of activities online, and that suggests that if we want to be ready to develop any kind of digital central bank product, we need to move faster than we thought was going to be necessary.” This is all looking a lot more urgent because of the speed with which technology is evolving Bank of Canada deputy governor Tim Lane Yet any tweak to money as we know it is bound to be a high-stakes proposition. Cash is hanging on for a reason: anyone can use it. You don’t need a smartphone to hand someone a cash payment. Physical currency also offers privacy, something authorities in democratic countries say they want to protect, even if it keeps some of them up at night over concerns such as money laundering. Still, cash was in decline even before the pandemic. As electronic and contactless payments have surged, the combined monetary value of cash transactions shrank to 0.9 per cent of total transactions in 2019, from 1.4 per cent in 2014, Payments Canada noted in its annual trends report. Cash is hanging on for a reason: anyone can use it. Photo by Francis Racine/Cornwall Standard-Freeholder/Postmedia Network files “What we are starting to see is extensions of trends that have already occurred,” Tracey Black, chief executive of Payments Canada, said. The trend away from cash has likely gained further momentum during the pandemic, partly because a number of people have likely come to see bills and coins as virus carriers. Payments Canada in a recent survey found that 42 per cent of Canadians polled were uncomfortable handling cash in general. Even post-pandemic, approximately 34 per cent of those surveyed did not expect to return to using cash as much as they did pre-COVID-19. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued The Bank of Canada urged retailers in the earlier days of the pandemic to keep accepting cash to ensure everyone could buy what they need. More recently, Bank of England research found that the risk of transmitting COVID-19 via banknotes is low. However, Payments Canada noted in its annual trends report that fewer than five per cent of Canadians have used a virtual currency, such as Bitcoin, to make a recent purchase. This is partly why the Bank of Canada in February said it saw no reason yet to create digital cash, although it also said it still had to be ready to do so just in case. Those statements came after Facebook Inc. created a stir last year by announcing plans to back a digital currency, Libra, which was recently rebranded as Diem. Members of the Diem Association — which still aims to launch a payment system with “Diem Coins” backed by cash and short-term government debt — include Ottawa-based Shopify Inc. and Spotify Technology SA. Facebook created a stir last year by announcing plans to back a digital currency, Libra. Photo by Dado Ruvic/Reuters Illustration files The Libra announcement caught the attention of policy-makers, who pushed back against the original vision, hence the recent rebrand and tweaks to the overall vision. Still, one of the concerns was that if enough people used something like a Libra/Diem “stablecoin,” it could sideline monetary gatekeepers such as the Bank of Canada. If too many Canadians conduct their financial affairs in a currency other than the dollar, they won’t much care about the setting of interest rates, making it harder for the central bank to manage inflation. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued This sort of concern, as well as innovation and the proliferation of digital payment options, has central banks thinking about their own central bank digital currency (CBDC). A survey of 66 central banks published earlier this year found approximately 80 per cent of them were doing some kind of CBDC-related work as of 2019, up from around 70 per cent a year earlier. The digital cash these banks could ultimately issue would not replace physical cash entirely, but might instead be accepted alongside it, as another form of payment backed by the government. CBDC, Payments Canada explained in another recent report, “is a digital liability of the central bank” that can be used to pay for things. In other words, similar to cash. The Bank of Canada would be on the hook for its digital currency, which citizens could use to spend on things the same way they would with bank notes. Issuing a CBDC could also “potentially counter” a threat such as Libra, Bank of Canada staffers said back in February. Some countries have already taken the CBDC concept for a test drive. Sweden’s central bank has piloted an “e-krona,” the Bahamas has launched a digital “Sand Dollar” and China is readying a central-bank-backed virtual currency of its own. In February, the Bank of Canada signalled it was working on a contingency plan for the day it might need a digital currency in the event that cash stopped being widely accepted or private digital currencies became all the rage. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued COVID-19 has hastened that planning. In November, now-former Bank of Canada senior deputy governor Carolyn Wilkins said the central bank had “stepped up our work on central bank digital currency, given that COVID-19 has accelerated the move to digital payments.” The Bank of Canada also joined with the European, Japanese, Swedish, Swiss, English and U.S. central banks in October in publishing “common foundational principles and core features” of CBDCs. According to those guidelines, issuing a digital currency shouldn’t upend the financial system, such as by causing a bank run if people pull their money from commercial lenders and put it into virtual cash. The central banks also said a digital currency should “coexist with and complement existing forms of money,” and spark innovation and efficiency. A conveyer belt with objects is used to demonstrate blockchain technology. Photo by David Becker/Getty Images files Central bankers identified 14 core features of any CBDC, including that it should be as easy to use as cash. There would also need to be a ledger to keep track of things, which could look similar to the blockchain technology that underpins Bitcoin. The central banks also see potential for digital currencies to be used in ways beyond everyday payments, such as when governments need to speedily send funds to citizens in need, as they have during the pandemic. The Bank of Canada back in February touched on a few other reasons as to why a digital currency would be helpful. For one, if everyone started using a digital currency created by a private company, a lender of last resort such as the Bank of Canada can’t start cranking out that currency to bail out commercial financial institutions in a crisis. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued Moreover, having a private company in charge of a widely used currency could go against the public’s interest, since that company would naturally be guided by a profit motive, not necessarily what’s best for society at large. The Bank of Canada maintains that it has an obligation to ensure that every Canadian has access to a unit of exchange they can use for free. That’s one of the reasons policy-makers are so protective of cash. But the main reason a central bank would issue a digital currency is probably control, specifically, the fear of losing control of monetary matters to a company or another country. The Bank of Canada designs and distributes bank notes, but also takes steps to help ensure money keeps its value by setting interest rates in a way that keeps prices stable. The monetary sovereignty of a country could be jeopardized if a company or another country’s digital currency gained enough traction. The Bank of Canada designs and distributes bank notes, but also takes steps to help ensure money keeps its value. Photo by Brent Lewin/Bloomberg files “A risk of stablecoins, so-called ‘cryptocurrencies’ and foreign CBDCs is that domestic users adopt them in significant numbers and use of the domestic sovereign currency dwindles,” the October report from the Bank of Canada and other central banks said. “In extremis, such a ‘digital dollarisation’ could see a national currency substituted by another with the domestic central bank gradually losing control over monetary matters.” That risk could be compounded depending on who is providing the hot new currency. China, noted Barry Campbell, a former parliamentary secretary to the minister of finance, has aimed to increase the global importance of its currency. Being a digital currency trailblazer could help those efforts. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued “It’s actually a geopolitical issue, it’s not just an issue over dollars and cents,” said Campbell, now president of Toronto-based lobbying firm Campbell Strategies Inc., of CBDCs. “This working group of the central banks … is an indication of just how seriously central banks are starting to look at this and, if you will, protect their turf.” Perhaps with this in mind, Bank of Canada staffers said in a June report that the central bank was looking at “multiple formats” for a digital currency, including the use of a “custom device that is engineered for universal access while securely storing and transferring a CBDC.” These universal access devices (UAD) “could incorporate attributes of cash and take advantage of specialized technologies,” the report said. Those cash-like features could include making it wallet-sized and allowing for small transactions. This working group … is an indication of just how seriously central banks are starting to look at this and, if you will, protect their turf Barry Campbell, former parliamentary secretary to the minister of finance “They have to be ready in case the necessity arises that they have to provide a digital alternative to cash,” said Thorsten Koeppl, an economics professor at Queen’s University in Kingston, Ont. Yet the death of cash is likely years away, if it ever actually happens. In April, for instance, Bank of Canada staffers, working with Ipsos and Statistics Canada, found that 74 per cent of the people they surveyed had no plans to go cashless. “I think inclusion is something that we really have to continue to monitor, and to make sure that there’s always an opportunity for people who prefer to use cash as tender to be able to purchase the things that they need,” Black, at Payments Canada, said. “I think cash is going to be around for quite some time.” Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued A digital Canadian currency is likely some ways off as well, even as Payments Canada modernizes its systems and the federal government examines the concept of open banking, which could allow consumers to securely share transaction data with third-party financial service providers. The Bank of Canada in February noted that it will take “several years” to build the capacity to issue a cash-like CBDC, in addition to support from the federal government. The bank also noted that there are other ways to respond to a cashless economy or a boom in private digital currencies, including targeted regulation and improved payment systems, both of which are in the works. The Bank of Canada building in Ottawa. Photo by Geoff Robins/AFP via Getty Images files A Canadian CBDC is not a sure thing and policy-makers at this point are really just getting cash’s affairs in order. In the meantime, there are still plenty of people relying on it. Kerr at the Salvation Army said the majority of donations had been coming in the form of cash tossed into the bubbles placed in and around places where people shop. Those bills and coins help fund the food banks, shelters and substance-use recovery programs the charity operates. This year’s Christmas kettle campaign was targeting $23 million in donations. Hitting that amount in a normal year would have taken plenty of work and generosity, even before factoring in declining cash use and the coronavirus pandemic. But the “touchless giving units” are expected to help. According to Tiptap, a pilot of the devices on Salvation Army kettles last year in Toronto led to three times the donation amounts at those bubbles compared to cash-only ones. “It is,” Kerr said, “a new day.” Financial Post • Email: gzochodne@nationalpost.com | Twitter: GeoffZochodne Share this article in your social network Share this Story: The Great Rethink: Cash is no longer king and the transition is going to be a high-stakes affair Copy Link Email Facebook Twitter Reddit Pinterest LinkedIn Tumblr In-depth reporting on the innovation economy from The Logic, brought to you in partnership with the Financial Post. Photo by Getty Images/iStockphoto Article Sidebar Share Share this Story: Fear of coronavirus-tainted money grows in U.S., opening new front in the war on cash Copy Link Email Facebook Twitter Reddit Pinterest LinkedIn Tumblr Trending Article content The signs began appearing around Seattle in the windows of Dick’s Drive-In, the city’s iconic burger chain: “In an abundance of caution, we ask you to please pay with credit or debit card if possible rather than cash.” Fear of dollars is now palpable in the U.S. epicentre of the coronavirus. We apologize, but this video has failed to load. Try refreshing your browser, or tap here to see other videos from our team. Fear of coronavirus-tainted money grows in U.S., opening new front in the war on cash Back to video And across the financial industry, a rigorous debate is brewing over how to address the public’s mounting concern that greenbacks might transmit COVID-19. Studies show it’s at least theoretically possible for other coronaviruses to survive on the dollar’s cotton-and-linen weave, though there’s little agreement on the actual risk of contagion. More On This Topic McDonald’s ordering kiosks have a major flaw, making them unusable for large number of customers Google Pay to offer personal chequing accounts in partnership with American bank, credit union In Sweden, cash is almost extinct and people implant microchips in their hands to pay for things Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued Behind the scenes, some industry groups and banks have been urging the Federal Reserve and Treasury Department to issue a statement assuring Americans that there’s minimal risk for using cash, according to people with knowledge of the discussions. The Fed, in turn, says it’s waiting for advice from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which so far has said the virus spreads primarily through person-to-person contact. In the meantime, the Fed has been putting notes repatriated from Asia in quarantine for up to 10 days to ensure it’s safe. The stakes are high for banks and companies handling electronic payments: Billions of dollars in profits hinge on whatever statement or policy authorities ultimately issue. On one side, small and mid-size banks are working to keep branches open so they can keep serving legions of business customers that refill their cash registers daily. Representatives from some lenders think it’s important for regulators to offer guidance on handling money, noting the risk of using currency is low — comparing it, say, to pushing an elevator button or grasping a handrail. ‘Hygienic’ Payments If, on the other hand, authorities take steps that discourage the use of dollar bills, it will buttress the credit card industry’s long-running “war on cash,” sending more transactions through their networks and to payment apps that collect fees. That could even boost interest-bearing credit card balances. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued Firms such as Visa Inc., Mastercard Inc., American Express Co., PayPal Holdings Inc. and a slew of large card-issuing banks would be among the top beneficiaries. Visa and Mastercard credit cards. Photo by Daniel Acker/Bloomberg files The virus may end up serving as a “trigger event” for wider acceptance of cards long term, either persuading retailers to start taking them or prompting the government to force them, said Lisa Ellis, an analyst independent research boutique MoffettNathanson. The shift would be especially dramatic in regions of the world where card use is still relatively uncommon, she said. “Digital payments are already viewed as good for society by governments because they help with financial inclusion, they drive tax revenue and eliminate corruption,” she said. “This is another reason: ‘Oh, and it’s hygienic too.'” Fighting for Poor And on another side are millions of Americans who lack access to bank accounts, as well as poor and rural communities with few if any branches serving residents and local businesses. Many of them rely on cash for commerce. Repeatedly in recent years, consumer advocates have fought stores and restaurants that try to simplify checkout by going “cashless.” Cities such as New York, Philadelphia and San Francisco passed laws requiring dollars be accepted. Some of those groups worry they’re about to face a national battle to allow cashless commerce in response to the coronavirus. “Going cashless is definitely not something that we particularly support,” said Eric Espinoza, an associate director at Neighborhood Trust Financial Partners, which helps provide financial services to low-income communities. “We certainly wouldn’t support it under a hasty decision-making environment in which you’re extremely reactive and potentially not as thoughtful about the repercussions.” Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued Despite the increased popularity of credit and debit cards in recent years, cash still remains one of the most popular ways to pay for things in the U.S., accounting for 26 per cent of all payments by consumers last year, according to data compiled by the Fed. Spare change and dollar bills are still overwhelmingly favoured for small purchases, accounting for about 50 per cent of payments under $10. Cash still remains one of the most popular ways to pay for things in the U.S. Photo by Daniel Acker/Bloomberg Roughly 25 per cent of Americans are either unbanked or underbanked — with black and Hispanic households making up the largest percentage of those lacking accounts, according to a study by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. More than half of unbanked households in the U.S. say they lack the funds to keep an account open. “If you want to go that direction, it’s going to take really thoughtful planning in order to deal with the questions of inclusivity,” John Thompson, chief program officer for the Financial Health Network. “There’s still really important, substantively sized sectors of the country that are operating outside of the mainstream financial system.” Paper currency in the U.S. is made from 75 per cent cotton and 25 per cent linen, according to the Treasury. That makes the surface of bills coarse and fibrous, allowing germs to adhere more easily and survive longer than they can on smooth objects. One study in 2013 showed the dollar has the ability to show “significant and prolonged carriage” of the dreaded Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus bacteria known as MSRA. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued A 2020 study of coronaviruses, which included SARS and MERS, showed the microbes can persist on surfaces for as long as nine days. That can be reduced significantly using ethanol-based disinfectant, according to the study, but cleaning a paper bill proves more difficult than a plastic surface like a desk. Confronted with COVID-19, the People’s Bank of China began using ultraviolet light and high-temperature ovens to disinfect cash coming in. It has also replaced old notes with newly minted bills. The People’s Bank of China began using ultraviolet light and high-temperature ovens to disinfect cash coming in. Photo by Fred Dugour/AFP/Getty Images files The Fed is staying in contact with the CDC to make sure it’s aware of the agency’s latest thinking on how the virus spreads, a spokeswoman for the central bank said. So far during the current outbreak, the Fed hasn’t widely enacted its longstanding protocol for banks handling bills suspected of being dangerous: First stacking them in “straps” of 100, then bundling those into larger bricks and packaging them in plastic bags with the word “CONTAMINATED” scribbled in permanent ink. Even if the virus compels more people to use cards, the world’s largest payments network will still be battling the broader slowdown in spending, especially in the travel sector. “In the near term, at this point, coronavirus is a clear negative because of disproportionate impact on international travel and consumer discretionary spend,” Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. analyst Harshita Rawat said in an interview. “People are just not traveling internationally and this is one of the most profitable businesses that these companies have.” Bloomberg.com Share this article in your social network Share this Story: Fear of coronavirus-tainted money grows in U.S., opening new front in the war on cash Copy Link Email Facebook Twitter Reddit Pinterest LinkedIn Tumblr In-depth reporting on the innovation economy from The Logic, brought to you in partnership with the Financial Post. The decision by 13 Republican senators to join most House Republicans in refusing to certify Joe Biden’s victory on Wednesday was quickly denounced by business groups, whose leaders voiced alarm at the threat it posed to a democracy that most had taken for granted. 'They don't like the idea America is a banana republic': Diehard Trump Republicans on collision course with business Back to video Their action “undermines our democracy and the rule of law,” warned the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, as a small business coalition blasted the “shameful complicity” of elected officials trying to help Trump “undermine the will of the voters.” Attempts to thwart the orderly transfer of power to Biden ran “counter to the essential tenets of our democracy,” added more than 180 New York executives including Accenture’s Julie Sweet, BlackRock’s Larry Fink and KKR’s Henry Kravis. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued man shouts as supporters of U.S. President Donald Trump gather in front of the U.S. Capitol Building January 6, 2021. Photo by Leah Millis/Reuters Pointedly, several of the statements argued that indulging baseless conspiracy theories — including that Biden only won thanks to mass voter fraud — was bad for business at a time when executives want Washington to tackle the economic fallout from COVID-19. Sowing further distrust in the political system “threatens the economic recovery … our country desperately needs,” said the Business Roundtable, which is led by Doug McMillon, Walmart chief executive. Richard Edelman, head of the eponymous public relations group, said: “CEOs are scared. They don’t like the idea America is a banana republic.” Supporters of U.S. President Donald Trump hold a rally outside the U.S. Capitol as they protest the upcoming electoral college certification of Joe Biden as U.S. President in Washington, D.C. on January 6, 2021. Photo by Olivier Douliery/AFP via Getty Images A Financial Times analysis found that the 13 senators supporting Trump’s last-gasp effort to cling to power have been bankrolled by some of corporate America’s biggest names. Together they received nearly US$2 million over the 2019-20 election cycle from the political action committees of companies including Koch Industries, Berkshire Hathaway, UPS and AT&T. Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, a Yale School of Management professor who convened a call of 33 top executives on Tuesday to discuss how business should respond, said there was “universal outrage” among a group that usually spanned the political spectrum. In a straw poll taken during the call, 88 per cent said officials supporting Trump’s stance were “aiding and abetting sedition”; just over half said they would consider cutting investment in the senators’ states; and 100 per cent said companies should warn lobbyists that they would no longer fund politicians denying the election results. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued “These business leaders are certainly not going to be investing in the divisive fringe,” Prof Sonnenfeld told the FT. Senators who should know better were “playing with fire”, added Tom Glocer, the Morgan Stanley director and former chief executive of Thomson Reuters. “If people are going to think twice before this political opportunism, we have to hit the only thing they care about” — campaign contributions. More On This Topic Live: U.S. Capitol on lockdown, one person shot as Trump supporters breach barricades Corporate America experiences ‘K-shaped’ recovery as largest businesses get bigger Virus relief package of cheques, tax breaks and business aid, the second biggest rescue in U.S. history, passes Congress Fed to maintain bond buys until ‘substantial’ economy gains seen However, some lobbyists in Washington cautioned that they did not expect a fundamental shift away from corporate donations to Republican lawmakers who have embraced Trump’s defiance of an orderly transition. They pointed out that corporate support is based on other issues that are important to them, and predicted that companies would wait to see how the furor over the confirmation played out. They added that the controversial incumbent senators supporting Trump’s efforts could be preferable to potential primary challengers from the right. Still, companies may face external pressure over their financial support for politicians who are pushing election fraud claims that have been rejected by a succession of courts and state officials. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued Steve Schmidt, a founder of The Lincoln Project, warned on Sunday night that the political action committee led by Bush-era Republicans would turn its fire on corporate donors who professed support for racial equality while funding politicians seeking to “throw out millions of Black votes.” In a series of tweets, Schmidt threatened that his well-funded group would not just draw attention to companies’ political spending, but would “foment employee rebellions and shareholder revolts” in its effort to “strangle the money flow” to Trump’s congressional supporters. Supporters of U.S. President Donald Trump protest inside the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. Photo by Saul Loeb/AFP via Getty Images Such pressure could embroil many of the most prominent U.S. companies, prompting renewed accusations of corporate hypocrisy. The FT’s analysis found that more than 20 Business Roundtable members — including EY, FedEx, Goldman Sachs and Microsoft — have funded at least one of the senators the group’s statement implicitly critiques. Despite its statement decrying efforts to overturn the election result, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce declined to say whether it would make vote certification a litmus test for its future Congressional endorsements. “That means there are no consequences to a representative or senator who does not heed the chamber’s (request),” said Bruce Freed, president of the Center for Political Accountability, which tracks corporate contributions. Even so, Freed said that companies faced “a moment of truth” with regard to their political spending. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued “They’re signing up to Business Roundtable statements… but their political dollars haven’t changed,” he said, predicting that investors would ask tougher questions about the issue at upcoming annual meetings. Daniella Ballou-Aares, chief executive of the Leadership Now Project, agreed that there had been “a step change” in the concerns of chief executives, following the senators’ announcement and the disclosure of Trump’s call pressing Georgia’s secretary of state to “find” extra votes to overturn his election loss in the state. Few companies thought when they were writing their cheques that they were giving licence for undermining democracy Daniella Ballou-Aares, Leadership Now Project Companies were interested in solving problems and many were now questioning the return on their investment in politicians showing little interest in finding bipartisan agreement, Ballou-Aares added. “If I were a government affairs office now I’d kind of want to ask for a refund if I’d supported those candidates,” Ballou-Aares said of the Republicans who planned to defy the election result. “Whatever one thinks about corporate investment in politics, I think few companies thought when they were writing their cheques that they were giving licence for undermining democracy.” © 2021 The Financial Times Ltd Share this article in your social network Share this Story: 'They don't like the idea America is a banana republic': Diehard Trump Republicans on collision course with business Copy Link Email Facebook Twitter Reddit Pinterest LinkedIn Tumblr In-depth reporting on the innovation economy from The Logic, brought to you in partnership with the Financial Post. Breadcrumb Trail Links Transportation Innovation Autos A $21-billion wager on who will build the Apple car — hint: it's a Canadian company Commentary: This Canadian manufacturer has its attractions for investors even without a Tim Cook order Author of the article: Bloomberg News Chris Bryant Publishing date:Jan 05, 2021 • • 4 minute read An employee carries auto parts at a Magna facility in Guelph, Ont., in 2018. Photo by Cole Burston/Bloomberg files Article Sidebar Share Share this Story: A $21-billion wager on who will build the Apple car — hint: it's a Canadian company Copy Link Email Facebook Twitter Reddit Pinterest LinkedIn Tumblr Trending Postmedia may earn an affiliate commission from purchases made through our links on this page. Article content A red-hot trend in the car industry is for new entrants such as Fisker Inc. to hand over the complicated and capital-intensive work of engineering and building vehicles to a contract manufacturer. Increasingly, cars are judged on their software and electronics so why bother wasting time and money on metal bashing? If Apple Inc. is indeed seriously considering launching its own vehicle, as press reports suggest, then it will almost certainly decide to outsource, as it does with the iPhone. Apple designs the phone and its operating system but employs Foxconn to assemble components into a handset. We apologize, but this video has failed to load. Try refreshing your browser, or tap here to see other videos from our team. A $21-billion wager on who will build the Apple car — hint: it's a Canadian company Back to video There’s at least one big contract manufacturer ready to take advantage of these seismic industry changes: Canada’s Magna International Inc. “If Apple is serious about building a car … Magna Steyr should build it,” says Evercore ISI analyst Chris McNally. Even if Apple doesn’t come knocking, the manufacturer is already advising tech groups and startups looking to enter the automotive business, and investors have taken notice. Magna’s shares have almost trebled since March, giving it a US$21-billion market value. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued For a great primer on Magna and its earlier car development work with Apple (those discussions didn’t ultimately go anywhere) do read this piece from 2016 by my Bloomberg Opinion colleague Alex Webb and Bloomberg News writers. Magna is one of the world’s biggest car-parts suppliers, having generated nearly US$40 billion of revenue in 2019 from products such as transmissions, vehicle cameras, mirrors and seating. The contract manufacturing subsidiary, Magna Steyr, is the really interesting piece. It builds niche premium vehicles at a factory in Graz, Austria, including the Mercedes G-Class 4×4, the electric Jaguar I-Pace and the BMW Z4 sportscar. Typically those companies choose to outsource the work, rather than retool or build a new production line, because the sales volumes are relatively small. In 2019 Magna assembled almost 160,000 vehicles — more than many carmakers produce — and generated US$6.7 billion of revenue from these activities. Together with joint venture partner Beijing Automotive Group Co. (BAIC) it recently added another facility in China, which is capable of producing 180,000 vehicles yearly. A north American plant might be next. If Apple is serious about building a car ... Magna Steyr should build it Evercore ISI analyst Chris McNally Magna’s client roster already extends well beyond the traditional automakers. Henrik Fisker’s eponymous car venture, for one, went public in October after merging with a special purpose acquisition company. A manufacturing and vehicle engineering partnership with Magna is key to Fisker’s asset-light approach. The latter often compares this to the Apple-Foxconn relationship and hopes that will avoid the production nightmares that bedevilled Tesla Inc. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued The Austrian Magna subsidiary is reportedly in talks about producing vehicles for Canoo Inc., another SPAC-backed car startup, while in China it’s started producing the Arcfox for BAIC’s electric vehicle offshoot. Other projects include helping Alphabet Inc.’s Waymo subsidiary integrate self-driving technology into vehicles and working with Sony Corp. to produce the futuristic Vision S prototype car. “It’s not a secret that almost every non-OEM interested in realizing its own complete vehicles is contacting us,” Frank Klein, Magna Steyr’s boss, told investors last year. You can see why new entrants may chose to work with a neutral party like Magna rather than partnering and sharing plans with an existing carmaker that might be a potential rival. As well as providing production capacity, Magna says it can handle the entire vehicle development process. The company was hired to turn chemicals billionaire Jim Ratcliffe’s Grenadier 4×4 into reality. More On This Topic Apple aims to produce a car that includes its breakthrough battery by 2024, sources say Apple aiming to build self-driving car by 2024, eyes ‘next level’ battery technology: sources Magna to develop driver assistance technology with Fisker Magna beats quarterly profit estimates, raises 2020 sales outlook The vehicles Magna builds in its factories usually include more of its own components and systems than is the case for cars it doesn’t make. It can also take a financial interest in the companies with which it works. If it does what it promises, Magna could end up owning 6 per cent of Fisker. Last year, it invested US$100 million in Waymo. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content continued These are welcome sweeteners because contract manufacturing’s economics are tough. The vehicle-building subsidiary produced a 2 per cent operating return on sales last year — much lower than the average in other parts of Magna’s business. And there are risks in adding manufacturing capacity for startups who may fail or decide to insource the work themselves. If Apple were to become a Magna customer it would drive the same hard bargain as it does with Foxconn, whose operating margins have shrunk to about 2 per cent. Apple’s is 24 per cent. Still, Magna’s shares look less dauntingly overvalued than many companies with one foot in the electric-vehicle future. Even after its blistering recent run, the stock is priced at less than 12 times forward earnings. The Canadian manufacturer has its attractions even without a Tim Cook order. He previously worked for the Financial Times. Separately, health officials said they had seen no sign yet of the variant, which emerged first in Britain and prompted many countries to introduce travel bans. We apologize, but this video has failed to load. Try refreshing your browser, or tap here to see other videos from our team. Canada to boost screening of UK travelers, sees no sign of mutated COVID-19 Back to video Although Ottawa imposed a 72-hour block on flights from Britain on Sunday, Blair said more steps were needed to handle people who had been in the country and then flown to Canada via Europe or the United States. Visitors to Britain during the previous two weeks prior to arrival in Canada will be referred to health officials for additional assessments, screening and questions. They will also have to go into quarantine for 14 days. “We believe (these measures) are among the strongest in the world,” Blair said, adding that those who lied about having not been in Britain could face imprisonment and big fines. Fewer than 2% of coronavirus cases in Canada have been linked to international travel, Blair said. A second wave of coronavirus is sweeping across Canada and authorities have only just begun to inoculate the population using Pfizer’s vaccine. Health Minister Patty Hajdu said a decision on whether to approve Moderna Inc’s vaccine should come very soon but gave no details. Ontario, Canada’s most populous province, on Monday announced a partial shutdown of some businesses starting Dec. 26 and banned most indoor gatherings. Cases continue to rise steadily and chief public health officer Theresa Tam said she was particularly worried about the increasing number of people being hospitalized at a time when health care workers are exhausted. “It’s going to be much more difficult for us to manage in the next few months,” she said. Photo by Tyler Anderson/National Post files Article Sidebar Share Share this Story: Younger Canadians are moving out of big cities at record levels Copy Link Email Facebook Twitter Reddit Pinterest LinkedIn Tumblr Trending Article content A record number of Canadians left major urban centres last year amid the pandemic, led by youth and young families. The nation’s three largest cities — Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver — saw a sharp jump in the number of citizens moving to suburbs, smaller towns and rural areas, according to Statistics Canada data released Thursday. A total of 87,444 people left those three cities between July 2019 and July 2020 for other parts of the same province, up from an average annual exodus of 72,686 the previous three years. We apologize, but this video has failed to load. Try refreshing your browser, or tap here to see other videos from our team. Younger Canadians are moving out of big cities at record levels Back to video It’s not a new phenomenon. People have been leaving the big cities in large numbers the last few years, replaced by new immigrants. But the pandemic has accelerated the trend, particularly among younger cohorts. More On This Topic If virtual conferences take hold, many jobs lost in the hospitality industry could be lost for good Canadians haven’t been this bullish about the housing market in at least ten years Burning Questions: Have we reached peak condo? This year mega cities turned into ghost towns — will they ever regain their pre-pandemic glory? Nearly a third of the increase in outflows were between the ages of 15 to 29, and 82 per cent were people under 45. The trend has had a clear impact on housing markets, where large suburban homes have seen the biggest increases in home values over the past year.
